src:
「少しでも力に」好天でボランティア続々…台風１９号から３週間

02 Nov 2019, 05:05



受付に列を作るボランティアら（２日午前９時３３分、長野市で）＝若杉和希撮影



道路脇にたまった災害ごみの搬出に追われる業者や自衛隊員（２日午前９時４７分、福島県いわき市で）＝大石健登撮影

　台風１９号で甚大な被害が出た東日本の被災地は２日、好天に恵まれ、朝からボランティアが続々と詰めかけた。久しぶりの週末の晴れ間で、１９号の被害発生から３週間となったこの日、被災者らと懸命の復旧作業が続いた。
　市街地が浸水した宮城県丸森町では仙台市などからのボランティアバスが朝から次々と到着。台風被害後最多となる約７００人が訪れ、ボランティアらは泥のかき出しなどに追われた。
　５１６世帯が床上浸水した同町では家財搬出などに人手が必要だが、人手不足が深刻で、県や町の社会福祉協議会が２日から仙台駅発着の送迎バスを運行した。３連休で５００人以上を受け入れるという。仙台市の会社員女性（４２）は「バスが出ると聞いて参加した。早く普通の生活を取り戻すための手助けができたらいい」と意気込んだ。
　長野市小島の北部ボランティアセンターでは、受け付け開始前から参加者が長蛇の列をつくった。作業を始めた長野県箕輪町の会社員男性（３２）は「被害の大きさを見て何かしなくてはと思った」と話した。
　岩手県宮古市は県内外から１３０人以上が集まった。これまで集まりがよくなかったが、県社協などの呼びかけもあり参加者は増加。初めて参加した盛岡市加賀野、大学職員男性（３８）は「今からでもできることがあるのか不安だったが、少しでも力になりたい」と話した。
　住宅など４５３３棟が浸水被害を受けた福島県いわき市は朝から、災害ごみの集中撤去作戦を開始。４日までの３日間で消防団、自衛隊員ら延べ１２００人にボランティアが加わり、仮置き場に運び出す。市内では臨時集積所の公園にも遊具が埋もれるほどのごみが持ち込まれ、衛生状態が悪化しつつある。清水敏男市長は「集積所を更地に戻し、生活空間から早くごみを取り除きたい」としている。
text:
Volunteer in good weather and even after a little effort ... 3 weeks from Typhoon # 19

02 Nov 2019, 05:05



Volunteers who queue up at the reception (9:33 am on the 2nd, in Nagano City) = Kazuki Wakasugi



Traders and Self-Defense Forces who are chased to carry out disaster garbage collected on the side of the road (9:47 am on the 2nd, in Iwaki City, Fukushima Prefecture)

The stricken area of eastern Japan that suffered severe damage from Typhoon No. 19 was blessed with fine weather on the 2nd, and volunteers packed up one after another. After a long weekend, it was three weeks after the 19th damage, and the recovery work continued with the victims.
Volunteer buses from Sendai City etc. arrived one after another in the morning in Marumori Town, Miyagi Prefecture, where the city area was flooded. About 700 people, the largest number after the typhoon, visited and volunteers were chased by mud.
In the same town where 516 households were flooded on the floor, manpower was necessary to carry out household goods, but the labor shortage was serious, and the social welfare council in the prefecture and town operated a shuttle bus to and from Sendai Station from the 2nd. It is said that more than 500 people will be accepted in three consecutive holidays. A female employee in Sendai City (42) said, “I participated when I heard that the bus would go out. I hope I could help you get back to normal life quickly.”
At the Northern Volunteer Center in Kojima, Nagano City, participants made a long line before the start of acceptance. “I thought I had to do something by looking at the magnitude of the damage,” said a man (32) from Minowa-cho, Nagano who started the work.
In Miyako City, Iwate Prefecture, more than 130 people gathered from inside and outside the prefecture. The gathering was not good so far, but the number of participants increased due to calls from prefectural associations. “I was worried about what I could do now, but I would like to be a little helped,” said Kagano, a university staff member, who participated for the first time.
Iwaki City, Fukushima Prefecture, where 4533 houses and other buildings were damaged by flooding, began a intensive removal operation for disaster waste in the morning. During the three days up to the fourth day, a total of 1200 volunteers including fire brigades and self-defense forces will be added to the temporary storage area. In the city, sanitation is getting worse because of the amount of garbage brought into the temporary collection park. Toshio Shimizu, the mayor, said, “I want to return the dump to the ground and remove the garbage quickly from the living space.”
